timeline.bodyText:
This should be unnecessary. SingleLogoutServiceMessageHandler are or can be ordered. The default runs last. So if all other handlers fail to support the service, this one should run by default automatically, and there is no need to check for service types as such, because other handlers should be given more priority with a lower order value.
Also, comparing types by String will never scale and will be unmaintainable. (This is already missing a service type, for example)
timeline.author: mmoayyed
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -23,4 +27,21 @@ public DefaultSingleLogoutServiceMessageHandler(final HttpClient httpClient,
         super(httpClient, logoutMessageBuilder, servicesManager, singleLogoutServiceLogoutUrlBuilder,
             asynchronous, authenticationRequestServiceSelectionStrategies);
     }
+
+    /**
+     * The default handler only applies on the CAS protocol services.
+     * For the SAML and OIDC protocols, specific handlers exist.
+     * For the OAuth protocol, no logout process is handled.
+     *
+     * The check of the service type is made by the class name not to add support-* dependencies.
+     *
+     * @param singleLogoutService the single logout service
+     * @param registeredService   the registered service
+     * @return whether the handler applies
+     */
+    @Override
+    protected boolean supportsInternal(final WebApplicationService singleLogoutService, final RegisteredService registeredService) {
+        val name = registeredService.getClass().getSimpleName();
+        return !"SamlRegisteredService".equals(name) && !"OidcRegisteredService".equals(name) && !"OAuthRegisteredService".equals(name);

replies.bodyText:
In general the order of execution is:

Protocol-specific ones, such as SAML2, OIDC, OAUTH, etc
1.1 Each handler checks for a service type and passes it onto the next, if it doesn't support the type
Default runs as a catch-all.
replies.author: mmoayyed

replies.bodyText: Yes, it makes sense. It will be much better.
replies.author: leleuj

timeline.bodyText:
All such settings should be controllable via CAS settings, in scenarios where a deployment would want to forcefully turn off logout.
Functionality related to these settings should also turn itself on/off based on the value.
timeline.author: mmoayyed

replies.bodyText: OK. I will do that. By default, I'll keep the logout enabled.
replies.author: leleuj

timeline.bodyText: Is there a need for an exp claim, and do we also need to account for time skew?
timeline.author: mmoayyed

replies.bodyText: As far as I can read, the spec: https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-backchannel-1_0.html#LogoutToken does not request an exp claim, nor a time skew. So I left that aside.
replies.author: leleuj

replies.bodyText: But this is something which can be easily revisited.
replies.author: leleuj

timeline.author: mmoayyed
mmoayyed

replies.bodyText: Sure. But I was waiting for the feedbacks before writing the tests in case I needed to change everything.
replies.author: leleuj

timeline.author: mmoayyed
mmoayyed
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -51,6 +51,10 @@
      * The access token hash.
      */
     String CLAIM_AT_HASH = "at_hash";
+    /**
+     * The session identifier claim.
+     */
+    String CLAIM_SESSIOND_ID = "sid";

replies.bodyText: I'd prefer to keep the "CLAIM" tag in the name...
replies.author: leleuj

timeline.author: mmoayyed
mmoayyed

timeline.bodyText: You should set an order to this handler runs before the default one if necessary.
timeline.author: mmoayyed

replies.bodyText: Sure, I will handle the order aspect of all message handlers.
replies.author: leleuj
